author: Potter
text: I have made many books about well-behaved people.

author: Potter
text: Now, for a change, I am going to make a story about two disagreeable people, called Tommy Brock and Mr. Tod.

author: Potter
text: Nobody could call Mr. Tod "nice."

author: Potter
text: The rabbits could not bear him; they could smell him half a mile off.

author: Potter
text: He was of a wandering habit and he had foxy whiskers; they never knew where he would be next.

author: Potter
text: One day he was living in a stick- house in the coppice [grove], causing terror to the family of old Mr. Benjamin Bouncer.

author: Potter
text: Next day he moved into a pollard willow near the lake, frightening the wild ducks and the water rats.

author: Potter
text: In winter and early spring he might generally be found in an earth amongst the rocks at the top of Bull Banks, under Oatmeal Crag.

author: Potter
text: He had half a dozen houses, but he was seldom at home.

author: Potter
text: The houses were not always empty when Mr. Tod moved OUT; because sometimes Tommy Brock moved IN; (without asking leave).

author: Potter
text: Tommy Brock was a short bristly fat waddling person with a grin; he grinned all over his face.

author: Potter
text: He was not nice in his habits.

author: Potter
text: He ate wasp nests and frogs and worms; and he waddled about by moonlight, digging things up.

author: Potter
text: His clothes were very dirty; and as he slept in the daytime, he always went to bed in his boots.

author: Potter
text: And the bed which he went to bed in was generally Mr. Tod's.

author: Potter
text: Now Tommy Brock did occasionally eat rabbit pie; but it was only very little young ones occasionally, when other food was really scarce.

author: Potter
text: He was friendly with old Mr. Bouncer; they agreed in disliking the wicked otters and Mr. Tod; they often talked over that painful subject.

author: Potter
text: Old Mr. Bouncer was stricken in years.

author: Potter
text: He sat in the spring sunshine outside the burrow, in a muffler; smoking a pipe of rabbit tobacco.

author: Potter
text: He lived with his son Benjamin Bunny and his daughter-in-law Flopsy, who had a young family.

author: Potter
text: Old Mr. Bouncer was in charge of the family that afternoon, because Benjamin and Flopsy had gone out.

author: Potter
text: The little rabbit babies were just old enough to open their blue eyes and kick.

author: Potter
text: They lay in a fluffy bed of rabbit wool and hay, in a shallow burrow, separate from the main rabbit hole.

author: Potter
text: To tell the truth--old Mr. Bouncer had forgotten them.

author: Potter
text: He sat in the sun, and conversed cordially with Tommy Brock, who was passing through the wood with a sack and a little spud which he used for digging, and some mole traps.

author: Potter
text: He complained bitterly about the scarcity of pheasants' eggs, and accused Mr. Tod of poaching them.

author: Potter
text: And the otters had cleared off all the frogs while he was asleep in winter--"I have not had a good square meal for a fort- night, I am living on pig-nuts.

author: Potter
text: I shall have to turn vegetarian and eat my own tail!" said Tommy Brock.

author: Potter
text: It was not much of a joke, but it tickled old Mr. Bouncer; because Tommy Brock was so fat and stumpy and grinning.

author: Potter
text: So old Mr. Bouncer laughed; and pressed Tommy Brock to come inside, to taste a slice of seed cake and "a glass of my daughter Flopsy's cowslip wine."

author: Potter
text: Tommy Brock squeezed himself into the rabbit hole with alacrity.

author: Potter
text: Then old Mr. Bouncer smoked another pipe, and gave Tommy Brock a cabbage leaf cigar which was so very strong that it made Tommy Brock grin more than ever; and the smoke filled the burrow.

author: Potter
text: Old Mr. Bouncer coughed and laughed; and Tommy Brock puffed and grinned.

author: Potter
text: And Mr. Bouncer laughed and coughed, and shut his eyes because of the cabbage smoke ..........

author: Potter
text: When Flopsy and Benjamin came back old Mr. Bouncer woke up.

author: Potter
text: Tommy Brock and all the young rabbit babies had disappeared!

author: Potter
text: Mr. Bouncer would not confess that he had admitted anybody into the rabbit hole.

author: Potter
text: But the smell of badger was undeniable; and there were round heavy footmarks in the sand.

author: Potter
text: He was in disgrace; Flopsy wrung her ears, and slapped him.

author: Potter
text: Benjamin Bunny set off at once after Tommy Brock.

author: Potter
text: There was not much difficulty in tracking him; he had left his foot- mark and gone slowly up the winding footpath through the wood.

author: Potter
text: Here he had rooted up the moss and wood sorrel.

author: Potter
text: There he had dug quite a deep hole for dog darnel; and had set a mole trap.

author: Potter
text: A little stream crossed the way.

author: Potter
text: Benjamin skipped lightly over dry-foot; the badger's heavy steps showed plainly in the mud.

author: Potter
text: The path led to a part of the thicket where the trees had been cleared; there were leafy oak stumps, and a sea of blue hyacinths --but the smell that made Benjamin stop was NOT the smell of flowers!

author: Potter
text: Mr. Tod's stick house was before him; and, for once, Mr. Tod was at home.

author: Potter
text: There was not only a foxy flavor in proof of it--there was smoke coming out of the broken pail that served as a chimney.

author: Potter
text: Benjamin Bunny sat up, staring, his whiskers twitched.

author: Potter
text: Inside the stick house somebody dropped a plate, and said something.

author: Potter
text: Benjamin stamped his foot, and bolted.

author: Potter
text: He never stopped till he came to the other side of the wood.

author: Potter
text: Apparently Tommy Brock had turned the same way.

author: Potter
text: Upon the top of the wall there were again the marks of

author: Potter
text: badger; and some ravellings of a sack had caught on a briar.

author: Potter
text: Benjamin climbed over the wall, into a meadow.

author: Potter
text: He found another mole trap newly set; he was still upon the track of Tommy Brock.

author: Potter
text: It was getting late in the afternoon.

author: Potter
text: Other rabbits were coming out to enjoy the evening air.

author: Potter
text: One of them in a blue coat, by himself, was busily hunting for dandelions.-- "Cousin Peter!

author: Potter
text: Peter Rabbit, Peter Rabbit!" shouted Benjamin Bunny.

author: Potter
text: The blue coated rabbit sat up with pricked ears--"Whatever is the matter, Cousin Benjamin?

author: Potter
text: Is it a cat? or John Stoat Ferret?"

author: Potter
text: "No, no, no!

author: Potter
text: He's bagged my family--Tommy Brock--in a sack --have you seen him?"

author: Potter
text: "Tommy Brock? how many, Cousin Benjamin?"

author: Potter
text: "Seven, Cousin Peter, and all of them twins!

author: Potter
text: Did he come this way?

author: Potter
text: Please tell me quick!"

author: Potter
text: "Yes, yes; not ten minutes since ... he said they were CATERPILLARS; I did think they were kicking rather hard, for caterpillars."

author: Potter
text: "Which way? which way has he gone, Cousin Peter?"

author: Potter
text: "He had a sack with something live in it; I watched him set a mole trap.

author: Potter
text: Let me use my mind, Cousin Benjamin; tell me from the beginning," Benjamin did so.

author: Potter
text: "My Uncle Bouncer has displayed a lamentable want of discretion for his years;" said Peter reflectively, "but there are two hopeful circumstances.

author: Potter
text: Your family is alive and kicking; and Tommy Brock has had refreshments.

author: Potter
text: He will probably go to sleep, and keep them for breakfast."

author: Potter
text: "Which way?"

author: Potter
text: "Cousin Benjamin, compose yourself.

author: Potter
text: I know very well which way.

author: Potter
text: Because Mr. Tod was at home in the stick house he has gone to Mr. Tod's other house, at the top of Bull Banks.

author: Potter
text: I partly know, because he offered to leave any message at Sister Cottontail's; he said he would be passing."

author: Potter
text: (Cottontail had married a black rabbit, and gone to live on the hill.)

author: Potter
text: Peter hid his dandelions, and accompanied the afflicted parent, who was all of atwitter.

author: Potter
text: They crossed several fields and began to climb the hill; the tracks of Tommy Brock were plainly to be seen.

author: Potter
text: He seemed to have put down the sack every dozen yards, to rest.

author: Potter
text: "He must be very puffed; we are close behind him, by the scent.

author: Potter
text: What a nasty person!" said Peter.

author: Potter
text: The sunshine was still warm and slanting on the hill pastures.

author: Potter
text: Half way up, Cottontail was sitting in her doorway, with four or five half- grown little rabbits playing about her; one black and the others brown.

author: Potter
text: Cottontail had seen Tommy Brock passing in the distance.

author: Potter
text: Asked whether her husband was at home she replied that Tommy Brock had rested twice while she watched him.

author: Potter
text: He had nodded, and pointed to the sack, and seemed doubled up with laughing.--"Come away, Peter; he will be cooking them; come quicker!" said Benjamin Bunny.

author: Potter
text: They climbed up and up;--"He was at home; I saw his black ears peeping out of the hole."

author: Potter
text: "They live too near the rocks to quarrel with their neighbors.

author: Potter
text: Come on, Cousin Benjamin!"

author: Potter
text: When they came near the wood at the top of Bull Banks, they went cautiously.

author: Potter
text: The trees grew amongst heaped up rocks; and there, beneath a crag, Mr. Tod had made one of his homes.

author: Potter
text: It was at the top of a steep bank; the rocks and bushes overhung it.

author: Potter
text: The rabbits crept up carefully, listening and peeping.

author: Potter
text: This house was something between a cave, a prison, and a tumbledown pigsty.

author: Potter
text: There was a strong door, which was shut and locked.

author: Potter
text: The setting sun made the window panes glow like red flame; but the kitchen fire was not alight.

author: Potter
text: It was neatly laid with dry sticks, as the rabbits could see, when they peeped through the window.

author: Potter
text: Benjamin sighed with relief.

author: Potter
text: But there were preparations upon the kitchen table which made him shudder.

author: Potter
text: There was an immense empty pie dish of blue willow pattern, and a large carving knife and fork, and a chopper.

author: Potter
text: At the other end of the table was a partly unfolded tablecloth, a plate, a tumbler, a knife and fork, salt cellar, mustard and a chair-- in short, preparations for one person's supper.

author: Potter
text: No person was to be seen, and no young rabbits.

author: Potter
text: The kitchen was empty and silent; the clock had run down.

author: Potter
text: Peter and Benjamin flattened their noses against the window, and stared into the dusk.

author: Potter
text: Then they scrambled round the rocks to the other side of the house.

author: Potter
text: It was damp and smelly, and over- grown with thorns and briars.

author: Potter
text: The rabbits shivered in their shoes.

author: Potter
text: "Oh my poor rabbit babies!

author: Potter
text: What a dreadful place; I shall never see them again!" sighed Benjamin.

author: Potter
text: They crept up to the bedroom window.

author: Potter
text: It was closed and bolted like the kitchen.

author: Potter
text: But there were signs that this window had been recently open; the cobwebs were disturbed, and there were fresh dirty footmarks upon the windowsill.

author: Potter
text: The room inside was so dark that at first they could make out nothing; but they could hear a noise--a slow deep regular snoring grunt.

author: Potter
text: And as their eyes became accustomed to the darkness, they perceived that somebody was asleep on Mr. Tod's bed, curled up under the blanket.--"He has gone to bed in his boots," whispered Peter.

author: Potter
text: Benjamin, who was all of atwitter, pulled Peter off the windowsill.

author: Potter
text: Tommy Brock's snores continued, grunty and regular from Mr. Tod's bed.

author: Potter
text: Nothing could be seen of the young family.

author: Potter
text: The sun had set; an owl began to hoot in the wood.

author: Potter
text: There were many unpleasant things lying about that had much better have been buried; rabbit bones and skulls, and chickens' legs and other horrors.

author: Potter
text: It was a shocking place, and very dark.

author: Potter
text: They went back to the front of the house, and tried in every way to move the bolt of the kitchen window.

author: Potter
text: They tried to push up a rusty nail between the window sashes; but it was of no use, especially without a light.

author: Potter
text: They sat side by side outside the window, whispering and listening.

author: Potter
text: In half an hour the moon rose over the wood.

author: Potter
text: It shone full and clear and cold, upon the house, amongst the rocks, and in at the kitchen window.

author: Potter
text: But alas, no little rabbit babies were to be seen!

author: Potter
text: The moonbeams twinkled on the carving knife and the pie dish, and made a path of brightness across the dirty floor.

author: Potter
text: The light showed a little door in a wall beside the kitchen fireplace --a little iron door belonging to a brick oven of that old-fashioned sort that used to be heated with faggots of wood.

author: Potter
text: And presently at the same moment Peter and Benjamin noticed that whenever they shook the window the little door opposite shook in answer.

author: Potter
text: The young family were alive; shut up in the oven!

author: Potter
text: Benjamin was so excited that it was a mercy he did not awake Tommy Brock, whose snores continued solemnly in Mr. Tod's bed.

author: Potter
text: But there really was not very much comfort in the discovery.

author: Potter
text: They could not open the window; and although the young family was alive the little rabbits were quite incapable of letting themselves out; they were not old enough to crawl.

author: Potter
text: After much whispering, Peter and Benjamin decided to dig a tunnel.

author: Potter
text: They began to burrow a yard or two lower down the bank.

author: Potter
text: They hoped that they might be able to work between the large stones under the house; the kitchen floor was so dirty that it was impossible to say whether it was made of earth or flags.

author: Potter
text: They dug and dug for hours.

author: Potter
text: They could not tunnel straight on account of stones; but by the end of the night they were under the kitchen floor.

author: Potter
text: Benjamin was on his back scratching upwards.

author: Potter
text: Peter's claws were worn down; he was outside the tunnel, shuffling sand away.

author: Potter
text: He called out that it was morning--sunrise; and that the jays were making a noise down below in the woods.

author: Potter
text: Benjamin Bunny came out of the dark tunnel shaking the sand from his ears; he cleaned his face with his paws.

author: Potter
text: Every minute the sun shone warmer on the top of the hill.

author: Potter
text: In the valley there was a sea of white mist, with golden tops of trees showing through.

author: Potter
text: Again from the fields down below in the mist there came the angry cry of a jay, followed by the sharp yelping bark of a fox!

author: Potter
text: Then those two rabbits lost their heads completely.

author: Potter
text: They did the most foolish thing that they could have done.

author: Potter
text: They rushed into their short new tunnel, and hid themselves at the top end of it, under Mr. Tod's kitchen floor.

author: Potter
text: Mr. Tod was coming up Bull Banks, and he was in the very worst of tempers.

author: Potter
text: First he had been upset by breaking the plate.

author: Potter
text: It was his own fault; but it was a china plate, the last of the dinner service that had belonged to his grandmother, old Vixen Tod.

author: Potter
text: Then the midges had been very bad.

author: Potter
text: And he had failed to catch a hen pheasant on her nest; and it had contained only five eggs, two of them addled.

author: Potter
text: Mr. Tod had had an unsatisfactory night.

author: Potter
text: As usual, when out of humor, he determined to move house.

author: Potter
text: First he tried the pollard willow, but it was damp; and the otters had left a dead fish near it.

author: Potter
text: Mr. Tod likes nobody's leavings but his own.

author: Potter
text: He made his way up the hill; his temper was not improved by noticing unmistakable marks of badger.

author: Potter
text: No one else grubs up the moss so wantonly as Tommy Brock.

author: Potter
text: Mr. Tod slapped his stick upon the earth and fumed; he guessed where Tommy Brock had gone to.

author: Potter
text: He was further annoyed by the jay bird which followed him persistently.

author: Potter
text: It flew from tree to tree and scolded, warning every rabbit within hearing that either a cat or a fox was coming up the plantation.

author: Potter
text: Once when it flew screaming over his head Mr. Tod snapped at it, and barked.

author: Potter
text: He approached his house very carefully, with a large rusty key.

author: Potter
text: He sniffed and his whiskers bristled.

author: Potter
text: The house was locked up, but Mr. Tod had his doubts whether it was empty.

author: Potter
text: He turned the rusty key in the lock; the rabbits below could hear it.

author: Potter
text: Mr. Tod opened the door cautiously and went in.

author: Potter
text: The sight that met Mr. Tod's eyes in Mr. Tod's kitchen made Mr. Tod furious.

author: Potter
text: There was Mr. Tod's chair, and Mr. Tod's pie dish, and his knife and fork and mustard and salt cellar, and his tablecloth, that he had left folded up in the dresser --all set out for supper (or breakfast) --without doubt for that odious Tommy Brock.

author: Potter
text: There was a smell of fresh earth and dirty badger, which fortunately overpowered all smell of rabbit.

author: Potter
text: But what absorbed Mr. Tod's attention was a noise, a deep slow regular snoring grunting noise, coming from his own bed.

author: Potter
text: He peeped through the hinges of the half-open bedroom door.

author: Potter
text: Then he turned and came out of the house in a hurry.

author: Potter
text: His whiskers bristled and his coat collar stood on end with rage.

author: Potter
text: For the next twenty minutes Mr. Tod kept creeping cautiously into the house, and retreating hurriedly out again.

author: Potter
text: By degrees he ventured further in--right into the bed- room.

author: Potter
text: When he was outside the house, he scratched up the earth with fury.

author: Potter
text: But when he was inside --he did not like the look of Tommy Brock's teeth.

author: Potter
text: He was lying on his back with his mouth open, grinning from ear to ear.

author: Potter
text: He snored peacefully and regularly; but one eye was not perfectly shut.

author: Potter
text: Mr. Tod came in and out of the bedroom.

author: Potter
text: Twice he brought in his walking stick, and once he brought in the coal scuttle.

author: Potter
text: But he thought better of it, and took them away.

author: Potter
text: When he came back after removing the coal scuttle, Tommy Brock was lying a little more sideways; but he seemed even sounder asleep.

author: Potter
text: He was an incurably indolent person; he was not in the least afraid of Mr. Tod; he was simply too lazy and comfortable to move.

author: Potter
text: Mr. Tod came back yet again into the bedroom with a clothes line.

author: Potter
text: He stood a minute watching Tommy Brock and listening attentively to the snores.

author: Potter
text: They were very loud indeed, but seemed quite natural.

author: Potter
text: Mr. Tod turned his back towards the bed, and undid the window.

author: Potter
text: It creaked; he turned round with a jump.

author: Potter
text: Tommy Brock, who had opened one eye--shut it hastily.

author: Potter
text: The snores continued.

author: Potter
text: Mr. Tod's proceedings were peculiar, and rather difficult (because the bed was between the window and the door of the bedroom).

author: Potter
text: He opened the window a little way, and pushed out the greater part of the clothes line on to the window- sill.

author: Potter
text: The rest of the line, with a hook at the end, remained in his hand.

author: Potter
text: Tommy Brock snored conscientiously.

author: Potter
text: Mr. Tod stood and looked at him for a minute; then he left the room again.

author: Potter
text: Tommy Brock opened both eyes, and looked at the rope and grinned.

author: Potter
text: There was a noise outside the window.

author: Potter
text: Tommy Brock shut his eyes in a hurry.

author: Potter
text: Mr. Tod had gone out at the front door, and round to the back of the house.

author: Potter
text: On the way, he stumbled over the rabbit burrow.

author: Potter
text: If he had had any idea who was inside it he would have pulled them out quickly.

author: Potter
text: His foot went through the tunnel nearly upon the top of Peter Rabbit and Benjamin; but, fortunately, he thought that it was some more of Tommy Brock's work.

author: Potter
text: He took up the coil of line from the sill, listened for a moment, and then tied the rope to a tree.

author: Potter
text: Tommy Brock watched him with one eye, through the window.

author: Potter
text: He was puzzled.

author: Potter
text: Mr. Tod fetched a large heavy pailful of water from the spring, and staggered with it through the kitchen into his bedroom.

author: Potter
text: Tommy Brock snored industriously, with rather a snort.

author: Potter
text: Mr. Tod put down the pail beside the bed, took up the end of rope with the hook--hesitated, and looked at Tommy Brock.

author: Potter
text: The snores were almost apoplectic; but the grin was not quite so big.

author: Potter
text: Mr. Tod gingerly mounted a chair by the head of the bedstead.

author: Potter
text: His legs were dangerously near to Tommy Brock's teeth.

author: Potter
text: He reached up and put the end of rope, with the hook, over the head of the tester bed, where the curtains ought to hang.

author: Potter
text: (Mr.

author: Potter
text: Tod's curtains were folded up, and put away, owing to the house being unoccupied.

author: Potter
text: So was the counterpane.

author: Potter
text: Tommy Brock was covered with a blanket only.)

author: Potter
text: Mr. Tod standing on the unsteady chair looked down upon him attentively; he really was a first prize sound sleeper!

author: Potter
text: It seemed as though nothing would waken him--not even the flapping rope across the bed.

author: Potter
text: Mr. Tod descended safely from the chair, and endeavored to get up again with the pail of water.

author: Potter
text: He intended to hang it from the hook, dangling over the head of Tommy Brock, in order to make a sort of shower-bath, worked by a string, through the window.

author: Potter
text: But, naturally, being a thin- legged person (though vindictive and sandy whiskered)--he was quite unable to lift the heavy weight to the level of the hook and rope.

author: Potter
text: He very nearly overbalanced himself.

author: Potter
text: The snores became more and more apoplectic.

author: Potter
text: One of Tommy Brock's hind legs twitched under the blanket, but still he slept on peacefully.

author: Potter
text: Mr. Tod and the pail descended from the chair without accident.

author: Potter
text: After considerable thought, he emptied the water into a wash basin and jug.

author: Potter
text: The empty pail was not too heavy for him; he slung it up wobbling over the head of Tommy Brock.

author: Potter
text: Surely there never was such a sleeper!

author: Potter
text: Mr. Tod got up and down, down and up on the chair.

author: Potter
text: As he could not lift the whole pailful of water at once he fetched a milk jug and ladled quarts of water into the pail by degrees.

author: Potter
text: The pail got fuller and fuller, and swung like a pendulum.

author: Potter
text: Occasionally a drop splashed over; but still Tommy Brock snored regularly and never moved,--except in one eye.

author: Potter
text: At last Mr. Tod's preparations were complete.

author: Potter
text: The pail was full of water; the rope was tightly strained over the top of the bed, and across the windowsill to the tree outside.

author: Potter
text: "It will make a great mess in my bedroom; but I could never sleep in that bed again without a spring cleaning of some sort," said Mr. Tod.

author: Potter
text: Mr. Tod took a last look at the badger and softly left the room.

author: Potter
text: He went out of the house, shutting the front door.

author: Potter
text: The rabbits heard his footsteps over the tunnel.

author: Potter
text: He ran round behind the house, intending to undo the rope in order to let fall the pailful of water upon Tommy Brock--

author: Potter
text: "I will wake him up with an unpleasant surprise," said Mr. Tod.

author: Potter
text: The moment he had gone, Tommy Brock got up in a hurry; he rolled Mr. Tod's dressing-gown into a bundle, put it into the bed beneath the pail of water instead of himself, and left the room also-- grinning immensely.

author: Potter
text: He went into the kitchen, lighted the fire and boiled the kettle; for the moment he did not trouble himself to cook the baby rabbits.

author: Potter
text: When Mr. Tod got to the tree, he found that the weight and strain had dragged the knot so tight that it was past untying.

author: Potter
text: He was obliged to gnaw it with his teeth.

author: Potter
text: He chewed and gnawed for more than twenty minutes.

author: Potter
text: At last the rope gave way with such a sudden jerk that it nearly pulled his teeth out, and quite knocked him over backwards.

author: Potter
text: Inside the house there was a great crash and splash, and the noise of a pail rolling over and over.

author: Potter
text: But no screams.

author: Potter
text: Mr. Tod was mystified; he sat quite still, and listened attentively.

author: Potter
text: Then he peeped in at the window.

author: Potter
text: The water was dripping from the bed, the pail had rolled into a corner.

author: Potter
text: In the middle of the bed, under the blanket, was a wet SOMETHING --much flattened in the middle, where the pail had caught it (as it were across the tummy).

author: Potter
text: Its head was covered by the wet blanket, and it was NOT SNORING ANY LONGER.

author: Potter
text: There was nothing stirring, and no sound except the drip, drop, drop, drip, of water trickling from the mattress.

author: Potter
text: Mr. Tod watched it for half an hour; his eyes glistened.

author: Potter
text: Then he cut a caper, and became so bold that he even tapped at the window; but the bundle never moved.

author: Potter
text: Yes--there was no doubt about it--it had turned out even better than he had planned; the pail had hit poor old Tommy Brock, and killed him dead!

author: Potter
text: "I will bury that nasty person in the hole which he has dug.

author: Potter
text: I will bring my bedding out, and dry it in the sun," said Mr. Tod.

author: Potter
text: "I will wash the tablecloth and spread it on the grass in the sun to bleach.

author: Potter
text: And the blanket must be hung up in the wind; and the bed must be thoroughly disinfected, and aired with a warming-pan; and warmed with a hot water bottle."

author: Potter
text: "I will get soft soap, and monkey soap, and all sorts of soap; and soda and scrubbing brushes; and persian powder; and carbolic to remove the smell.

author: Potter
text: I must have a disinfecting.

author: Potter
text: Perhaps I may have to burn sulphur."

author: Potter
text: He hurried round the house to get a shovel from the kitchen-- "First I will arrange the hole--then I will drag out that person in the blanket.

author: Potter
text: He opened the door.

author: Potter
text: Tommy Brock was sitting at Mr. Tod's kitchen table, pouring out tea from Mr. Tod's teapot into Mr. Tod's teacup.

author: Potter
text: He was quite dry himself and grinning; and he threw the cup of scalding tea all over Mr. Tod.

author: Potter
text: Then Mr. Tod rushed upon Tommy Brock, and Tommy Brock grappled with Mr. Tod amongst the broken crockery, and there was a terrific battle all over the kitchen.

author: Potter
text: To the rabbits underneath it sounded as if the floor would give way at each crash of falling furniture.

author: Potter
text: They crept out of their tunnel, and hung about amongst the rocks and bushes, listening anxiously.

author: Potter
text: Inside the house the racket was fearful.

author: Potter
text: The rabbit babies in the oven woke up trembling; perhaps it was fortunate they were shut up inside.

author: Potter
text: Everything was upset except the kitchen table.

author: Potter
text: And everything was broken, except the mantelpiece and the kitchen fender.

author: Potter
text: The crockery was smashed to atoms.

author: Potter
text: The chairs were broken, and the window, and the clock fell with a crash, and there were handfuls of Mr. Tod's sandy whiskers.

author: Potter
text: The vases fell off the mantelpiece, the cannisters fell off the shelf; the kettle fell off the hob.

author: Potter
text: Tommy Brock put his foot in a jar of raspberry jam.

author: Potter
text: And the boiling water out of the kettle fell upon the tail of Mr. Tod.

author: Potter
text: When the kettle fell, Tommy Brock, who was still grinning, happened to be uppermost; and he rolled Mr. Tod over and over like a log, out at the door.

author: Potter
text: Then the snarling and worrying went on outside; and they rolled over the bank, and down hill, bumping over the rocks.

author: Potter
text: There will never be any love lost between Tommy Brock and Mr. Tod.

author: Potter
text: As soon as the coast was clear, Peter Rabbit and Benjamin Bunny came out of the bushes.

author: Potter
text: "Now for it!

author: Potter
text: Run in, Cousin Benjamin!

author: Potter
text: Run in and get them! while I watch the door."

author: Potter
text: But Benjamin was frightened--

author: Potter
text: "Oh; oh! they are coming back!"

author: Potter
text: "No they are not."

author: Potter
text: "Yes they are!"

author: Potter
text: "What dreadful bad language!

author: Potter
text: I think they have fallen down the stone quarry."

author: Potter
text: Still Benjamin hesitated, and Peter kept pushing him--

author: Potter
text: "Be quick, it's all right.

author: Potter
text: Shut the oven door, Cousin Benjamin, so that he won't miss them."

author: Potter
text: Decidedly there were lively doings in Mr. Tod's kitchen!

author: Potter
text: At home in the rabbit hole, things had not been quite comfortable.

author: Potter
text: After quarreling at supper, Flopsy and old Mr. Bouncer had passed a sleepless night, and quarrelled again at breakfast.

author: Potter
text: Old Mr. Bouncer could no longer deny that he had invited company into the rabbit hole; but he refused to reply to the questions and reproaches of Flopsy.

author: Potter
text: The day passed heavily.

author: Potter
text: Old Mr. Bouncer, very sulky, was huddled up in a corner, barricaded with a chair.

author: Potter
text: Flopsy had taken away his pipe and hidden the tobacco.

author: Potter
text: She had been having a complete turn out and spring cleaning, to relieve her feelings.

author: Potter
text: She had just finished.

author: Potter
text: Old Mr. Bouncer, behind his chair, was wondering anxiously what she would do next.

author: Potter
text: In Mr. Tod's kitchen, amidst the wreckage, Benjamin Bunny picked his way to the oven nervously, through a thick cloud of dust.

author: Potter
text: He opened the oven door, felt inside, and found something warm and wriggling.

author: Potter
text: He lifted it out carefully, and rejoined Peter Rabbit.

author: Potter
text: "I've got them!

author: Potter
text: Can we get away?

author: Potter
text: Shall we hide, Cousin Peter?"

author: Potter
text: Peter pricked his ears; distant sounds of fighting still echoed in the wood.

author: Potter
text: Five minutes afterwards two breathless rabbits came scuttering away down Bull Banks, half carrying, half dragging a sack between them, bumpetty bump over the grass.

author: Potter
text: They reached home safely, and burst into the rabbit hole.

author: Potter
text: Great was old Mr. Bouncer's relief and Flopsy's joy when Peter and Benjamin arrived in triumph with the young family.

author: Potter
text: The rabbit babies were rather tumbled and very hungry; they were fed and put to bed.

author: Potter
text: They soon recovered.

author: Potter
text: A new long pipe and a fresh supply of rabbit tobacco was presented to Mr. Bouncer.

author: Potter
text: He was rather upon his dignity; but he accepted.

author: Potter
text: Old Mr. Bouncer was forgiven, and they all had dinner.

author: Potter
text: Then Peter and Benjamin told their story--but they had not waited long enough to be able to tell the end of the battle between Tommy Brock and Mr. Tod.
